newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Sinopec cuts crude supply to coastal refineries.
newsitem.headline: Sinopec cuts crude supply to coastal refineries.

text.p: China's state-refiner Sinopec has cut crude supplies to coastal refineries in 1997 in order to divert more supplies to in-land refineries, Sinopec sources said on Thursday.
The sources declined to say what proportion of Sinopec's crude would be diverted in favour of in-land refineries.
But they said the shift in policy had been made in order to help raise domestic prices to international levels.
"The state policy is to narrow the gap between international and domestic prices," said an official with Sinopec in Beijing.
"The move is just to comply with international standards. We can't always offer subsidies," the official said.
The move is likely to add to the pressure on China's imports of crude oil, above that already produced from the growing economy.
China's imports reached 22.62 million tonnes in 1996, customes figures showed.

State media reported in January that China expected to import 34 million tonnes, indicating a rise of 50 percent. Analysts said previously that they did not expect imports to rise so sharply in 1997, and the most optimistic said they expected imports to reach no more than 30 million tonnes.
Sinopec is China's biggest refinery, accounting for about 80 percent of the country's total refining capacity of 4.3 million barrels per day (bpd).
Chinese sources said the shift in policy will help bring China closer to the international crude markets.
Domestic price controls on crude sales have been rising since the 1980s and late in 1996 reached 1,085 yuan per tonne, or about $17.43 per barrel.
